awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Multi-messenger Titans: Probing The Dynamics & Environments Of Supermassive Binary Black Holes
awd_abstract_narration:
It is now known that nearly every galaxy contains at its center, a supermassive black hole, with a mass millions to billions of times greater than the mass of the Sun.  If a supermassive black hole is in a dense environment, it can be detected by the light emitted by gas and dust falling into it.  Such an object is called an active galactic nucleus (AGN).  It is also known that some of these titanic objects exist in pairs, called supermassive binary black holes (SMBBHs), which are expected to eventually spiral into each other and collide, producing ripples in spacetime, or gravitational waves (GWs).  These GWs cause tiny variations in the timing of rapidly spinning compact former stars called pulsars.  By measuring these timing variations using multiple radio telescopes in what is called a pulsar timing array (PTA), astronomers expect to infer the existence of such GWs.  A research team at Vanderbilt University will perform the first end-to-end coherent multi-messenger (MM) search for SMBBHs using the synthesis of precision pulsar timing array data with optical observations of the time-varying brightness and spectra of AGN. The methods resulting from the project will forecast the expected properties of the first MM binary detection in the 2020s, including the likely binary environment and host galaxy characteristics.  The investigators will also establish a Vanderbilt node of Student Teams of Astrophysics ResarcherS (STARS), a highly successful national program established by the NANOGrav PTA team. The work will involve undergraduate students from Vanderbilt and Fisk (a nearby historically black university), who will be directly involved in pulsar and gravitational-wave research. 

This project will forge a path to the unambiguous identification of SMBBHs at sub-parsec separations, helping to resolve the perplexing enigma of this heretofore missing population. While dual AGN have been observed at separations from kiloparsecs down to seven parsecs, there are no unambiguously identified SMBBHs at sub-parsec separations. Some candidate sub-parsec pairs have been identified as quasi-periodic optical-flux or radial-velocity variations in AGN, but this is severely hampered by intrinsic disk and environmental noise processes that can mimic periodic behavior over short baselines. Only PTA data can directly infer the presence of SMBBHs through detection of their ~nanohertz-frequency GWs. By combining PTA GW searches with large photometric and spectroscopic surveys, this project will leverage the strength of multiple messengers to arbitrate existing candidates, forecast the expected properties and constraints on the first MM binary detection, and fuse the information provided by different messengers into a complete portrait of SMBBH dynamics at sub-parsec separations. This proposal represents a dramatic leap forward in understanding how EM signatures of SMBBHs track the GW signal.  This project advances the goals of the NSF Windows on the Universe Big Idea.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At the center of nearly every galaxy lies a massive black hole. Despite being only approximately a thousandth of the mass of the total galaxy, this black hole has a huge influence on its host. Moreover, these black holes can reach masses of billions to tens of billions of Suns. As galaxies wander and merge over the history of the Universe, the black holes in each galaxy can sink within the gravitational potential of the new combined galaxy. Over time these black holes can find each other, pairing up to form a massive black-hole binary system. The black holes in this system will eventually spiral into each other and collide, producing ripples in spacetime, or gravitational waves, as they do so. These gravitational waves spread out through the Universe, eventually passing through our galaxy to cause tiny variations in the timing of pulses emitted from rapidly spinning compact former stars called pulsars. By measuring these timing variations using multiple radio telescopes in a pulsar timing array, astronomers can infer the existence of such gravitational waves. These gravitational waves are the only way to directly sense black holes, as they emit no light of their own. Yet if there is matter present and swirling around the black holes, we could sense them by their gravitational influence on the emitted light. 

To this end, a team at Vanderbilt University carried out a program of study to investigate how these electromagnetic-wave signatures would evolve in tandem with gravitational-wave signatures, which kinds of systems would be likely to have both kinds of detectable signals, and the necessary advances needed to forge a path toward a combined multi-messenger probe of candidate massive black-hole binary systems. The work connected signatures of electromagnetic variability—which include variable accretion onto each black hole, Doppler boosting of radiation from disks around each black hole, and gravitational lensing of disk flux by each black hole—to the orbital phase of the binary system, which in turn enabled connections to its gravitational-wave signal produced in pulsar timing arrays. We found that relativistic Doppler boosting (caused by a black hole and associated disk moving towards or away from an observer’s line of sight) produced the cleanest signature to track a black-hole binary in light. The team delineated the binary parameter space for which both gravitational and electromagnetic wave signals are detectable, finding that binary systems with total mass greater than a few billion Suns and orbital periods greater than a couple of hundred days are favorable for detection. This dovetailed well with work on post-processing cosmological simulation data to find the most likely properties of galaxies that would harbor a detectable massive black-hole binary system in gravitational waves; it was found that these galaxies are among the most massive, with low specific star formation rate, and higher than average stellar metallicity. 

The team also studied efficient gravitational-wave data-analysis strategies to search over many binary candidates, finding that the component from when the gravitational wave passes each pulsar is sub-dominant for parameter estimation, allowing potentially big savings on computational time. The team then began stitching all studies together to make a combined muti-messenger analysis framework, where data from pulsar timing arrays and electromagnetic time-domain surveys would feed into a search pipeline to constrain the properties of a putative massive black-hole binary jointly. Initial results look promising, where the constraints from each messenger are complementary to one another, such that the combination makes a meaningful impact on parameter constraints. The team is now finishing the analyses to write an article and deploy the code. In synthesis, this project represents a dramatic leap forward in understanding how electromagnetic signatures of massive black-hole binaries track their gravitational-wave signal. Throughout the project, the team also played key leadership roles in the discovery and astrophysical interpretation of the nanohertz-frequency gravitational-wave background found by NANOGrav adn other pulsar timing array collaborations. 

The team expanded the reach of their work and the knowledge they created by establishing a Vanderbilt node of Student Teams of Astrophysics ResarcherS (STARS), a highly successful national program established by the NANOGrav collaboration. The work directly involved undergraduate students from Vanderbilt in ranking candidate pulsar observations and gravitational-wave data analysis from cutting-edge NANOGrav and International Pulsar Timing Array datasets. Beyond this STARS team, the PI worked one-on-one with several undergraduate students who produced two first-author peer-reviewed articles on multi-messenger astronomy. In the latter stages of the project, the PI and associated team members contributed to the founding of the Nashville chapter of the popular Astronomy On Tap outreach program, where students, postdocs, and faculty give informal and engaging astronomy-themed presentations to members of the public.
